Hi, there's a calculation I want to check whether I've gotten correct, as well as if this falls into some larger story.

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a small category and P:Cop→SetP : \mathcal{C}^\text{op} \to \mathbf{Set}P:Cop→Set a presheaf. We can use Isbell conjugation to obtain a functor P∗:C→SetP_* : \mathcal{C} \to \mathbf{Set}P∗​:C→Set defined by P∗(c):=Nat(P,Hom(−,c))P_*(c) := \text{Nat}(P, \text{Hom}(-, c))P∗​(c):=Nat(P,Hom(−,c)).

Suppose P∗P_*P∗​ is representable by r∈Ob(C)r \in \text{Ob}(\mathcal{C})r∈Ob(C) with universal element α:P⇒Hom(−,r)\alpha : P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r)α:P⇒Hom(−,r). There are two main claims I want to check.

Claim 1: Suppose there is a u∈P(r)u \in P(r)u∈P(r) such that the composite natural transformation P⇒Hom(−,r)⇒PP \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r) \Rightarrow PP⇒Hom(−,r)⇒P is the identity. Then uuu is a universal element for PPP, i.e. PPP itself is represented by rrr.

Proof: It suffices to check that the composite Hom(−,r)⇒P⇒Hom(−,r)\text{Hom}(-, r) \Rightarrow P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r)Hom(−,r)⇒P⇒Hom(−,r) is the identity. But since this is a map r→rr \to rr→r, using the universal property it suffices to check the composite P⇒Hom(−,r)⇒P⇒Hom(−,r)P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r) \Rightarrow P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r)P⇒Hom(−,r)⇒P⇒Hom(−,r) is equal to α\alphaα. (So α\alphaα is "epimorphic" but only for maps Hom(−,r)→Hom(−,s)\text{Hom}(-, r) \to \text{Hom}(-, s)Hom(−,r)→Hom(−,s), I guess?). And this follows by rebracketing.

Claim 2: Suppose PPP sends colimits to limits. Then PPP is representable.

Proof: By unfolding definitions, we see that rrr represents the coend ∫cc×P(c)\int^c c \times P(c)∫cc×P(c), which may be realised as a colimit over a suitable category of elements. Thus PPP sends this coend to an end. This means the maps P(αs(x)):P(r)→P(s)P(\alpha_s(x)) : P(r) \to P(s)P(αs​(x)):P(r)→P(s) for s∈Ob(C),x∈P(s)s \in \text{Ob}(\mathcal{C}), x \in P(s)s∈Ob(C),x∈P(s) form a universal wedge. By considering the singleton set, we deduce the existence of a u∈P(r)u \in P(r)u∈P(r) such that P(αs(x))(u)=xP(\alpha_s(x))(u) = xP(αs​(x))(u)=x for all s∈Ob(C),x∈P(s)s \in \text{Ob}(\mathcal{C}), x \in P(s)s∈Ob(C),x∈P(s). But that's precisely the statement that P⇒Hom(−,r)⇒PP \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r) \Rightarrow PP⇒Hom(−,r)⇒P is the identity! Thus, by claim 1, PPP is representable.
The reason I ask is that something akin to this seems to come up in the kan extension formulae for representing objects (of which the formulae for adjoints fall out as a special case).

Another thing that I think is always true is that P∗P_*P∗​ preserves limits, so is much more “likely” to be representable than PPP, which may or may not send colimits to limits. It seems like the strategy here to represent P is to find a representation of P∗P_*P∗​ (relatively straightforward), and then convert this to a representation of PPP itself (harder).

The last thing ("P∗P^*P∗ preserves limits") is true, but I'm not sure that the "likelihood" consequence follows. It really depends if you have some other presentation of P∗P^*P∗ around that you can exploit to show representability!

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

The last thing ("P∗P^*P∗ preserves limits") is true, but I'm not sure that the "likelihood" consequence follows. It really depends if you have some other presentation of P∗P^*P∗ around that you can exploit to show representability!

I guess what I was thinking is P∗(x)=∫cHom(P(c),Hom(c,x))≅∫cHom(P(c)×c,x)≅Hom(∫cPc×c,x)P_*(x) = \int_c \text{Hom}(P(c), \text{Hom}(c, x)) \cong \int_c \text{Hom}(P(c) \times c, x) \cong \text{Hom}(\int^c Pc \times c, x)P∗​(x)=∫c​Hom(P(c),Hom(c,x))≅∫c​Hom(P(c)×c,x)≅Hom(∫cPc×c,x). So, as long as C\mathcal{C}C has the coend ∫cc×P(c)\int^c c \times P(c)∫cc×P(c), P∗P_*P∗​ is representable.

If it helps, I wrote up some thoughts on this in more detail in my most recent article - https://pseudonium.github.io/2026/01/27/Baby_Yoneda_3_Know_Your_Limits.html, under the section "Representing the Dual". The case I discuss there is for preorders, which avoids some of the subtler points regarding naturality and size issues for arbtirary categories.
Incidentally, that coend is precisely the weighted colimit you use in computing a left kan extension of the yoneda embedding along the identity C -> C
Maybe one sense in which “more likely” can be made precise is that PPP representable always implies P∗P_*P∗​ representable, but the reverse isn’t necessarily true.

Actually, thinking on this a little more - since P∗P_*P∗​ necessarily preserves limits, we have that P∗ representable   ⟺  (P∗)∗ representable P_* \text{ representable } \iff (P_*)^* \text{ representable }P∗​ representable ⟺(P∗​)∗ representable . So you never need to apply this trick more than once!

I see, more likely in that there are potentially more presheaves P with P^* representable that there are representable presheaves! Okay, I can buy that. The connection with ends and Kan extensions is nice, I hope people absorb that.
(Regarding veracity: I haven't spotted any errors but I also haven't made much effort to verify things :) )

As an example, presheaves of the form P(−)=Hom(−,A)∐Hom(−,B)P(-) = \text{Hom}(-, A) \coprod \text{Hom}(-, B)P(−)=Hom(−,A)∐Hom(−,B) are almost never representable - the reason is that the universal element has to either be a morphism into AAA or a morphism into BBB, but this is then preserved by precomposition. So e.g. if the universal element is a morphism into AAA, you're stuck with morphisms into AAA and can't reach any morphisms into BBB.

However, in this case P∗(−)=Hom(A,−)×Hom(B,−)P_*(-) = \text{Hom}(A, -) \times \text{Hom}(B, -)P∗​(−)=Hom(A,−)×Hom(B,−), which is representable whenever AAA and BBB have a coproduct! So this gives a large class of non-representable presheaves for which P∗P_*P∗​ is representable.
Thinking about it more carefully, it might actually be impossible for Hom(−,A)∐Hom(−,B)\text{Hom}(-, A) \coprod \text{Hom}(-, B)Hom(−,A)∐Hom(−,B) to be representable.

Ruby Khondaker (she/her) said:

Suppose P∗P_*P∗​ is representable by r∈Ob(C)r \in \text{Ob}(\mathcal{C})r∈Ob(C) with universal element α:P⇒Hom(−,r)\alpha : P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r)α:P⇒Hom(−,r). There are two main claims I want to check.

Am I wrong to assume that a representable for P∗:C→Set P^* : \mathcal{C} \to \mathbf{Set} P∗:C→Set is given by a natural transformation Hom(r,−)⇒P∗ \mathrm{Hom}(r, -) \Rightarrow P^*Hom(r,−)⇒P∗ instead?
Yes, but by yoneda that’s an element of P∗(r)P_*(r)P∗​(r), which by definition is a natural transformation P⇒Hom(−,r)P \Rightarrow \text{Hom}(-, r)P⇒Hom(−,r).
Perhaps related - I recently learned about the definition of a [[total category]], which appears to be a category for which P∗P_*P∗​ is always representable.

It appears that exercise 2.17.2 in Borceux Vol 1 is a corollary of this result. The task is to show that a functor F has a limit if the forgetful functor from the category of cones on F has a colimit. The observation which connects these two is that a cocone on the forgetful functor is precisely a natural transformation P -> Hom(-, r), with P(c) the set of cones on F with tip c, viewed as a presheaf. P automatically sends colimits to limits, so it is representable iff P_* is representable, which implies the exercise.

I've really enjoyed this thread. It almost certainly has interesting ramifications in an enriched setting (e.g. in an abelian setting where more limits and colimits coincide, and the absolute limits/colimits are similarly more interesting).

Thank you! It’s definitely given me an interesting alternative perspective on computing representations. Results like the adjoint functor theorem seem to be about providing sufficient conditions to compute ∫cc×P(c)\int^c c \times P(c)∫cc×P(c). I suppose this has emphasised the special role that limits and colimits play among all representable functors?
